title: Which sentence makes sense, 'He succeeded at third attempt' or 'He succeeded a third attempt'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Neither is quite as clear as it should be. The addition of just one or two little words would improve that. He succeeded at his third attempt.He succeeded on his third attempt.He succeeded with his third attempt.He succeeded in his third attempt.

Which sentence makes sense, "He succeeded at third attempt" or "He succeeded a third attempt"? In that sentence, succeeded is intransitive: it does not take a direct object, so ‘…a third attempt’ is an indirect object, which requires a preposition. ‘Third attempt’ requires a determiner. Correct alternatives are: ‘He succeeded at a third attempt.’ ‘He succeeded on his third attempt.’
